title: Unbelievable dog row at popular café divides Aussies
description: A café in one of Australia's trendiest suburbs has found itself at the centre of a dog saga, prompting intervention from the local council and sparking a divide among locals.
content:
The owners of a popular café have blasted council for fining them after a customer made a complaint about their dog walking around in the kitchen.

La Bottega in Leichhardt, Sydney's inner west, was hit with an $880 penalty, with Inner West Council warning further fines could follow if the practice continued.

It came after a disgruntled diner left a one-star review, claiming they were thrown out by the 'unprofessional' owners after complaining about their dog, Pongo.

The dachshund had become a mascot of the café, with its owners breaking the news he would no longer be around to greet diners.

'With a very heavy heart, I need to share some news,' they wrote in an Instagram post.

'The council has fined us $880 and informed me that they'll continue to fine us daily if Pongo is here during the week.'

The café owners explained they had been forced to find other arrangements for someone else to look after their dog during business hours.

'This means our little Pongo will now be spending his weekdays in daycare, and sadly won't be here to welcome you and your puppy friends for the time being,' they wrote.

Despite the setback, the café promised the fight wasn't over.

'But there's always light at the end of the tunnel,' the post read.

'I'll keep fighting to bring Pongo back where he belongs, greeting our customers in the place he loves to call home,' it added.

The post followed a scathing one-star review accusing the café of breaking the law and lashing out at concerned customers.

'Please be aware that they have dogs roaming freely inside, including the kitchen area, which is very clearly illegal,' the review read.

'When we questioned, the explanation was 'they are the owners!'.

The reviewer said they lodged a complaint with the council, which likely led to the $880 fine.

'I took a picture as I am intending to report it to the council and the Food Authority, and when they saw that they became very disrespectful and literally threw us out of the café,' the review said.

'In my 15 years in Australia, this is the first time I have seen such unprofessional and arrogant behaviour.

'They can be sure I will be reporting them to the council and the Food Authority and follow it up to the end.'

The post was met with many people agreeing with the complainant.

'But the dog was in the kitchen which is a health and safety hazard?? Why are these commenters fighting to have a dog in a restaurant kitchen?' said one person.

'So all these people saying it's ok would be fine if it were rats instead? I'm a dog lover, but do not want a dog in the kitchen of a restaurant,' another said.

'If you don’t like it, don’t go,' one said.

'And how many people have pets at home that are in the kitchen and on counters I wonder,' another said.

Daily Mail contacted La Bottega and Inner West Council for comment.
summary: The owners of a Sydney café, La Bottega, have criticised the Inner West Council for fining them $880 after a customer complained about their dog, Pongo, walking around in the kitchen. The council has warned that further fines could be issued if the practice continues. The café owners have been forced to find someone else to care for their dog during business hours. This follows a one-star review by a customer who claimed they were thrown out of the café by the owners after complaining about Pongo. The review accused the café of breaking the law by allowing dogs to roam freely inside, which is clearly illegal. Despite this setback, the café has promised to keep fighting to restore Pongo to his rightful home.
shortSummary: A popular Sydney café faced backlash for fining its owners $880 for allowing their dog in the kitchen, leading to a customer complaint and subsequent fines.

Sydney
Sydney - one of the largest cities in Australia - is the capital of the state of New South Wales. It is also the oldest city in the country, with the first settlers arriving in 1788. Major sites of interest include the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Sydney Opera House and the world-famous Bondi Beach. Celebrity Sydneysiders include actors Hugh Jackman, Russell Crowe and Nicole Kidman as well as rock band AC/DC.

argos_summary: La Bottega café owners in Leichhardt were fined $880 by Inner West Council after a customer complained that their dog, Pongo, was roaming the kitchen, a breach of health and safety rules. The owners announced Pongo would be in daycare during business hours and vowed to fight the fine, while a disgruntled diner left a one‑star review accusing the café of illegal pet policy and poor customer service. The incident sparked debate online, with many locals supporting the complaint and questioning the safety of having a dog in a kitchen. The café’s social media post highlighted their plans to bring Pongo back once the issue is resolved, but warned of potential daily fines if the dog remains on premises.
